text: Bird's-eye view. We circle lazily above the forest. Through a break in the trees, we catch an occasional glim of a prostrate form on the ground. As the circling camera gets closer we see that the form is a human body.
I'm not sorry.
A bead of sweat trickles down her cheek. Then: a blinding flash of light obliterates her face.
I am sorry.
A tear wells in Puff's eye and runs down his face. Anothe blinding flash of light.
I don't even know what sorry means  anymore.
As Nathan speaks, a trickle of blood drips down his face  from his out-of-frame forehead. Another blinding flash of light.

It's a frenetic hand-held shot as Lila is pulled from a p car and dragged into the precinct house. Cameras flash.  Reporters shout questions. Lila attempts to shield her fa from view, but she is handcuffed and can only manage to h her shoulders.

A ratty interrogation room. Institutional green walls. Beat-up file cabinets. Dark. A bit of fluorescent light s in through the frosted glass door. Lila, thirties, sits a the end of a long table. A reel-to-reel tape recorder whi in front of her. She is smoking. Three fat, mean-looking  cops sit in shadows at the other end of the table. One of the cops eyes her lasciviously. Lila's hand shakes as she brings the cigarette to her mouth.
I'm not sorry. So I spend the rest  of my life in jail. So what? I've  been in jail my whole life anyway. A  jail of blood and tissue and coursing  hormones...
One of the cops sighs and massages the bridge of his nose It's going to be a long night.
...a jail called the human body.
The lascivious cop smiles lasciviously at Lila's referenc to "human body."
My soul held prisoner in this reeking,  stench-ridden bag of bones and  entrails. A bag of feces and piss  and fibroid cysts in my tits and  precancerous moles on my sun-damaged  back...
The lascivious cop gags, then vomits on the floor. Lila d on her cigarette, calmer now.
At least now I'll be able to blame  the state, not God, for my  incarceration.

Puff, thirties, dirty, scraggly hair and beard but in a c business suit, testifies before a congressional committee The auditorium is filled with reporters and spectators. P sits in front of a microphone, counsel at his side. He po himself a glass of water, drinks, clears his throat, then speaks: stentorian, confident.
I am sorry, gentlemen, sorry for all  of us. Your's is a complicated, sad  world.
This is a revelation to the assembled crowd. People whisp to each other.

And I never knew that. I was living  a life of simplicity, of purity,  when I was ripped out of my Eden and  immersed in this harshness. Some  would argue that the life I was living  was not a human life at all. And,  gentlemen, I don't have any clever  retort. I am not a philosopher. The  only thing I know is that I am sorry,  sorry for my expulsion from Eden,  sorry for my Lila rotting in her  jail cell, and sorry for Nathan...  rotting in his grave.
Nathan, thirties, in a white robe, sits alone at a white  table. Everything is white except for an oozing bullet wo in Nathan's temple.

I don't even know what sorry means  anymore. It's odd. When I was alive  I knew -- maybe it was all I knew --  but here sorry is meaningless. Love  is meaningless. Jealousy is  meaningless. Ambition is meaningless.  Everything that motivated my every  breath while I was alive is  meaningless now. (beat) I guess that's how I can be sure I'm  really dead.
Lila watches the slowly churning tape recorder reels, fix The cop who vomited is mopping it up. The other two are  sipping coffee. Lila talks.
My story begins when I was twelve.
(checks watch) Jesus.

It's got that faded, "memory" look. Twelve year old Lila  hurries home from school, books clutched to her chest. Other kids walk along the street in pairs or groups, laug and chatting. Lila walks alone, a worried scowl on her fa
Something terrible happened when I  was twelve.

Colors are still muted. It looks to be somewhere in the e 70's based on the preponderance of Bay City Rollers poste on the wall. Twelve year old Lila enters the room, closes the door, locks it, rattles the doorknob to make sure tha the door is really locked. She draws the shades. She pull some t-shirts from her dresser drawer and stuffs them int the space between the bottom of the door and the floor.
(muffled) Hey, no fair!
Drop dead, Eric.
Lila stands nervously in front of the full-length mirror her closet door. She takes a deep breath and begins to  unbutton her shirt, watching herself carefully in the mir

Something terrible started to happen  to my body when I was twelve. My  mother said because of it I would  never be able to get a man, so I  should get used to the idea of  dedicating my life to the pursuit of  knowledge, or religion... or whatever.

Lila's shirt is now unbuttoned. She pulls it open. She is wearing a training bra over the very beginning of breast  buds. On the chest above the bra, and on her stomach belo it, is hair. Dark curly hair. She stares at it, touches i cautiously. Then she starts to cry. She crouches into a b and weeps.
The doctor said...
Old fashioned office. Twelve year old Lila sits on the  examination table, her shirt off. An elderly male doctor  touches the hair, fingers it. Her mother looks on.
(to the mother) It's hormonal. Nature is a funny and  complex thing. It could get worse  with time.
Young Lila turns to the camera.
By the time I was twenty I looked  like an ape.
The cop who vomited, gags again. Lila stares at him. Her  face is hard, blank. She stubs out her cigarette.
Puff testifies before the committee.

I don't think there's anyone in the  world who doesn't know by now that I  was raised in the wilderness by an  ape. Well, to be fair, by a man who  thought himself an ape, but it amounts  to the same thing gentlemen, does it  not?
This has a faded, "memory" look also. A naked, bearded, d middle-aged man and a naked, dirty ten year old Puff walk along like apes, crouched over and dragging their knuckle
My father escaped from a New Jersey  mental institution in 1963.
It's raining and deserted. Puff's father, in pajamas, com tearing around the corner. He runs crazily towards the ca waving his arms, puffing out his cheeks.
He had been committed the previous  year after applying one too many  times at our local zoo for the job  of "apprentice ape."

Puff's father passes a newspaper vending machine, stops,  goes back and examines the headline. It reads: President  Kennedy Assassinated. Puff's father looks heavenward and  clutches at his temples in despair.
My father saw what the human race  had come to while he was... in  captivity. He felt something had to  be done to create a better world.
Puff's father climbs out a second story window with a sma bundle in his arms. He runs off into the night.
He stole little me from my mother,  his ex-wife, and raised me, with  love and tenderness and respect, as  an ape like himself.
Puff looks pointedly at the congressman.
Apes don't assassinate their  presidents, gentlemen.
The congressmen are shamed: they look down, they take not they mumble instructions to the assistants seated behind  them.
An adult Puff and his now older father sit on the forest  floor and pick bugs off each other and eat them.
Until quite recently I believed myself  to be an ape, although I didn't know  specifically what type. Apes don't  think in terms of type.
Puff testifies.
It might be argued, gentlemen, that  apes don't even know that they are  apes. In retrospect, however, I'd  say that I was a pygmy chimp.
Puff holds up an illustration of a pygmy chimp. Several  reporters run from the room: a scoop!
Nathan talks to nobody in particular.

I have to say I always hated apes.  Of course I don't any longer. I don't  even know what hate means now. But  while alive, I hated apes. I blame  my parents. I mean, I don't blame  them. I don't know what blame is,  really, anymore, but I think they  influenced me in my ape-hating  tendencies.

Faded colors. Ten year old Nathan in a bow tie and shortp suit walks along with his uptight, British parents. They arrive at the ape pen. Nathan is excited. He jumps u and down. The apes jump up and down also.
Monkeys! Look, mama, monkeys!
(clamping down on his  shoulder) Nathan, those are not monkeys. Those  are apes. Mountain Gorillas to be  precise.
There is a commotion off screen. Two uniformed attendants drag Puff's father, straitjacketed and kicking and scream like an ape, past Nathan and his parents.
I am not a human being! I am an  animal!
Nathan, his father, and the other zoo patrons look on  curiously, a little frightened. Nathan's mother chooses t ignore it.
And furthermore... Tell him, Harold.

(distracted) Uh... (then by rote) We must never act like apes, son.  For you see, The ape is our closest  biological relative -- specifically  the pygmy chimp. (holds up the same  illustration of a  pygmy chimp that  Puff showed the  congressional  committee) A single chromosome separates us.  But you know what truly separates us  from the apes, what makes us better  than apes?
No, papa. What?

Culture. Civilization. Refinement.  If we do not have these as humans,  then we might as well be living in  pens and throwing our feces about,  masturbating in public... (beat, a reverie) ...sniffing red swollen female rump...
Enough, Harold.
Lila lights a new cigarette with her spent one. She drags

Oh, I had sexual urges. I had the  urge to merge, officers. Inside I  was 100% Grade A female. (laughs derisively) But what self-loathing I felt! Who  would have someone as repulsive, as  unladylike as me? I did everything I  could to shield the world from this  repulsiveness.

Stockings hang over the shower curtain rod. The window sh is drawn. Towels are stuffed in the space under the door. twenty year old naked Lila is covered with shaving cream, face to feet. She is shaving. There is a pounding on the  door.
Lila, what are you doing in there? I  need to get ready for my date.
Nothing! I'll be out in a minute!
The door opens. Lila freezes.
Look, I'll just... (stops in her tracks  when she sees Lila) What the...?
Lila is mortified.
Lila is sitting in her bathrobe on her bed and staring ou the window. There is a bit of shaving cream behind her ea Her roommate runs back and forth getting ready for her da
I don't know why you didn't tell me  about this.
It's embarrassing, okay?
It's not so bad. (beat) So, it just keeps growing?
Yeah, Natalie. It's hair. It grows.
Well, don't jump down my throat. I'm  just trying to help.
How is that helping, Natalie? How  exactly?
Look, if you're going to be like  that... You should be appreciative  that I'm interested.
Why, because I'm a freak and you are  beautiful, and you are being nice  enough to come down to my freak,  nonbeautiful level and act concerned  about my repulsive troubles?
(pegged) You're fucked up, Lila. (out the door) Why don't you fucking try electrolysis  or something? Figure it out for  chrissake.
The door slams. Lila hugs her knees to her chest.
At sixty dollars an hour, electrolysis  was not a feasible solution. I  explored my alternatives.

Twelve year old Lila walks sadly through an art museum. s looks at various old portraits of men. She studies their  facial hair. When she turns a corner, she is shocked to s a large Renaissance painting of a naked woman entirely co with fur. She hurries to it. She looks at the placard nex to the painting. It is a painting of Mary Magdalene.

I remember once coming across a  painting of Mary Magdalene entirely  covered with fur. I guess that's  where I got the idea that maybe the  Catholic Church might be a place  that encouraged excessive hair growth  in its women.
Lila, in a nun's habit, is on her knees praying.
So I became a nun.
Heavenly Father... (sighs) ...please let this hair go away.
But my prayers were always so selfish.
A bunch of naked women dance and chat around a campfire. Lila is there, pretty hairy. So are many of the other wom
I tried being a lesbian separatist.
(chanting) A woman without a man / Is like a  fish without a bicycle.
But I guess I just wasn't attracted  to women, even hostile, man-hating,  hairy ones who wore sensible shoes.

Lila, in a full beard, sits on a throne before a crowd of gawking, dumb-looking, mouth-breathing children. Next to on a separate stage is a sour-looking, middle-aged midget man sitting on a throne, staring blankly into space.
For a while I was a professional  circus freak.

Lila, in a Santa suit, with beard sprayed white, sits on throne in front of a crowd of gawking, dumb-looking, mout breathing children. One of them is on her lap. Next to he sits the sour midget, dressed in an elf suit.
During the holiday season, they made  us wear costumes.
(depressed) Ho ho ho.
That's not real.
The kid pulls Lila's beard.
Ow! You little fuck.
Aside from the great dental, this  occupation was not pleasant.

Lila walks home. She's wrapped in winter clothing, but we can still see a bit of her white beard. It's snowing. The street is deserted. She spots a lighted window, she peers in. It's a warm family scene. Large group of chatting,  laughing people. Fire in the fireplace. Big turkey on the table.
They say the holidays are difficult  for a lot of people.
Lila looks down the street and sees dozens of lonely-look people peering forlornly in warmly lit windows. Some on  ladders to peer in second-floor windows. Lila sighs.

The room is lit with candles. Lila finishes shaving herse all over. Then she takes the double-edged blade out of th razor and climbs into the a bathtub filled with warm wate She is about to slice her wrists.
I decided there was something poetic  about killing myself with a razor  blade.

On the shelf next to the tub a little gray mouse watches intently. At first she is startled, but then she and the  creature seem to be communing. His little black beady eye reflect the light. Lila starts to cry. She puts down the  blade.
Lila wipes a tear from her eye.
The way that mouse looked at me.  There was no judgement. It didn't  care if I had hair all over my body.  I was just what I was. I felt so  free. Do you understand what I'm  saying?
The cops look up, on the spot. It seems their minds were  elsewhere.
Something about a mouse, right?
Lila sighs.

We see a tent in a clearing. A smoking campfire. There is rustling inside the tent. Lila steps out naked. She is co with fur. She pours a cup of coffee, and stands, comforta in her skin, watching the world around her. Squirrels jump from tree to tree, birds look down at her. She smiles.

Birds and squirrels and rocks and  trees didn't seem to judge my hair.  I felt at peace when there were no  humans around. I figured out a way  to spend as much time as possible  with no people around. I became a  nature writer.
Lila picks up a pad and pen from a rock, sits on the rock and writes.

A woman under a hair drier reads a book intently. We see first sentence of the chapter: "Last night I almost died this mountain top." We hear Lila's dramatic reading compe with the very loud sound of the hair drier.
Last night I almost died on this  mountain top, and the irony is I had  never felt more alive.

There is a violent, violent storm. The hair drier drone h turned into the explosive noise of rain beating down in s and wind howling at fifty miles an hour. Branches crack.  Lila's tent blows over, revealing her huddled there with sleeping bag wrapped around her like a blanket.

I knew it was coming when in late  afternoon, a thunderhead drifted  over, sneaking in like kids through  the back door of a movie theater,  forced casual. It turned the sky a  queer shade of green. A green that  said "watch out, baby, this is gonna  hurt like hell." I could've  hightailed, but that would be  cheating. Part of the Nature  experience is recognizing its mastery  over you, your smallness in the face  of it.

Lightning hits a tree nearby. It falls with a smack  practically on top of Lila. She screams, then defiantly  stands, throwing off the sleeping bag. The wind and rain  whip her hair around her head. She laughs with amazing gu and raise her arms like a runner winning a marathon.
As Nietzsche said, what does not  kill me makes me stronger, and that  goes double if you're a woman.
We see many copies of a book entitled "Wind in my Hair" b Lila Jute.
I became a successful nature writer.

We see a woman under a hair drier reading "Wind in my Hai We pull back to see that a long row of women under hair d are reading Lila's book. They all stand defiantly, proudl knocking their hair driers up and back as they do. The blowing hair driers whip the women's wet hair around  their heads. The blowing hair drier drone is unbearably l
Then I became a famous nature writer.  I said to myself, fuck humanity...
A big display of the book "Fuck Humanity" by Lila Jute. A long line of women with beautifully coiffured hair snakes out of the store.

...and I became a recluse. I had a  menagerie of animals at my house.  They loved me because I was me. They  loved me on the days I shaved. They  loved me on the days I didn't. For a  while this was enough.

Lila lies in bed tapping on a lap top. A dog lies with he and licks her knee. She seems to enjoy it, and gets lost a reverie. The dog morphs into a handsome man, kissing he knee and working his way up her thigh and under her night Lila is getting seriously hot and bothered. Her head loll But the reverie dissipates and the man turns back into a rooting around her crotch with his cold nose. She pushes away. The dejected dog gets off the bed.
By the time I was thirty I was very,  very horny.
Lila gets out of bed and studies herself in the mirror. S brushes her hands against her hairy body.
I had to have a man in my... life.  At any cost. I would become what I  needed to become to achieve this. I  would become a hairless lie.
The mirror image of Lila shimmers and turns into Lila wit no body hair. Lila all made-up and with a smart new hairs She assumes a coquettish pose and smiles cutely at hersel
I was rich enough for electrolysis  by this time, so I began the long  arduous process of having each  inappropriate hair burned out of my  body at the root.
Lila talks. One of the cops is doodling. One is picking w from his ear with a pencil. One is reading a paperback no under the table.
This is when everything changed, and  this is where my confession really  begins.
The cops look up.
Lila lies shirtless on a table while Rose, her fifty year old electrologist, works on her back.
Progress!
Ouch. Yeah?
Oh yes, honey. Getting to be smooth  smooth smooth all over. Smooth as a  baby's butt.
I love it, Rose. I'm getting to be a  real girl.
You still in the market for a real  boy?
Always. Ow.
(beat) Cause there's this guy. My brother  knows him. Might be right up your  alley.
Tell me. I could use someone up my  alley.
(playing dumb) I don't get that. Is that sexual?
Shut up and tell me.
Handsome, thirties, psychologist...
Loves animals? Ouch. Must love  animals, Rose.
Loves animals. Loves you.
What do you mean?
Somehow it came up that you were a  friend of mine. Mr. handsome, animal- loving psychologist said he would  love to meet you.
Holy shit. Your brother didn't tell  him about the nature of our  relationship, did he?
My brother is discreet.
(rubbing her hand  over her jaw) Won't he be able to tell?

My brother says the guy's a thirty- five year old virgin, so maybe he  won't know how women usually feel.  Plus he's got bad eyesight, almost  legally blind, which is helpful in  this situation. Plus he's got an  extremely small penis, of which he  is "mortifyingly ashamed", so chances  are he'll be so grateful for any non- judgmental attention, that he'll be  yours forever.
God, he must be really close to your  brother to tell him such personal  stuff.
Yeah, well my brother is his shrink.
It's a chi-chi place. Lila sits at a table with Nathan,  fastidious in dress and manner. There is an awkward first silence. She sneaks a glance at his crotch. Then:
Meditations on a Banana Slug was a  delightful read.
Thank you so much. I love slugs. All  slugs, not just banana slugs.
As do I.

They're so even keel. They forge  ahead with slow determination. They  don't get distracted or side-tracked.  They don't care what they look like. They don't care that people look at  them and go, "Ewww. A slug."
They don't seem to be especially ego  driven, this is true.
You've got to respect that.
I have to say that I'm not there  yet.
Where?
Slugdom. Sluggishness. Whatever you'd  call it. I'm not there yet. I still  have many human characteristics.
That's not necessarily a bad thing.
Yes. I suppose not. But still. One  would like to move along. To move  beyond.
I'm not sure we can escape our  natures. Believe me I've tried. I'm  not even so sure anymore that we  should want to.

I love that you said that. It makes  me feel a bit lighter. I've been  rather heavy lately. Thinking about  my childhood. Realizing how much a  product I am of my upbringing. (beat, cautiously) I've been seeing someone. A therapist.
(feigning surprise) You are a therapist, right?
No no. I'm a psychologist, but I do  research. I'm a behaviorist. I work  with animals. Mice at the moment.
I hope you don't perform any of those  dreadful torture experiments, Nathan.
Heavens no. My work now is... Right  now I'm teaching mice... well, table  manners, to be candid.
(beat. doesn't know  what to say) How's it going?
Quite well, really. It's a lot of  work. A lot of reinforcement, mostly  positive. Right now I've gotten two  of my subjects to use napkins. Tiny  napkins of course.
Paper or cloth?
I hope you don't think me daft. It's  important work. It's part of a larger  sociological experiment. I'm federally  funded.
What's the larger experiment?
It's my thesis that if table manners  can be taught to mice, they can be  taught to humans.
Going out on a limb, aren't you,  Nathan?

(speech) The truth is most people don't have  table manners today. And when the  foundations of civilized society  crumble and disappear, civilized  society in its entirely follows  closely at its heels.
I'm not sure.
(stridently) Courtesy, decorum, manners, are all  sadly lacking from our daily  intercourse. Rudeness, vulgarity,  meanness are the norm.
We are animals after all.
Ergo if I can teach table manners to  mice, I can teach them to humans. If  I can teach table manners to humans,  I can save the world.
Nathan blushes. Lila stares at him for a long moment. Her thoughts are unreadable.
Lila lies on her back. Rose works on her breasts.
So?
I really like him, Rose. He's so... (searching) ...passionate about his work.
My brother says he likes you, too.
(pleased) Really?
Yeah. Says he likes you even more  than he likes his own mother. And  according to my brother Nathan's  abormally close with his mother.
Nathan talks.
I began going to a therapist when I  was in my thirties, because I felt  that I wasn't enjoying life the way  my friends were. (beat) After a time my childhood came up.
It is another sepia scene. Nathan as a ten year old sits the table with his parents. There is a bowl of salad in f of each of them. Everyone's head is bowed in prayer.
Lord, we thank you for this bountiful  gift we are about to receive.
Amen.
Eyes open, and young Nathan reaches for a fork to eat the salad. He grabs the wrong fork. Mother's eyes widen in ho
My God, no! My God! (disappointed) Oh, Nathan.
Nathan looks up.
That is the wrong fork, young man. (to father) Harold, tell the boy.
That is the wrong fork, young man.
(panicky) I'll use the right one. I'm sorry. I  forgot.
Harold, tell the boy more.
Too late. Go to your room.
But...
Harold! Tell the boy again.
(looking at mother) No "buts." Go to your room now.
(looking at father) And?
And think about what you've done.
Adult Nathan sits on the couch, dabbing at his eyes. Wendall, his therapist sits across from him and writes  something in his notebook.
And do you think maybe this early  childhood indoctrination has something  to do with your interest in table  manners in the present.
Nathan thinks long and hard about this. He seems to be re straining, squinting his eyes. Finally:
I don't think so. No.
Wendall nods and scribbles something on his pad.
Why do you ask?
Wendall looks up.

Everything's white. People in lab coats hustle back and f Nathan, also in a lab coat, is hovering over a Lucite  encasement. Inside we see two white mice, both attached t electrodes. They sit in little chairs at a little table. front of each of them is a little plate of salad and thre forks of varying size under Lucite domes. Nathan nods to his pretty French assistant, Gabrielle, wh presses a button. The Lucite domes over the salads lift. Tentatively both mice reach for a fork. There is a tiny p of velcro on each mouse's paw and a tiny piece of velcro each of the forks. The first mouse picks the correct fork and stabs it into the salad and eats happily, relieved. T second mouse picks the wrong fork. Nathan presses a butto which sends the mouse flying off his chair with an electr shock. The correct mouse keeps eating, unconcerned. Natha makes a note in his notebook. Gabrielle watches Nathan as he writes, enchanted.

The table is elegantly set, candlelit. Lila sits at it wh Nathan fusses in the kitchenette. Something classical waf over from the stereo in the living room. Nathan places a  salad in front of Lila and sits across from her with his salad.
It looks wonderful.
You look wonderful. I'm on top of  the world tonight, Lila. Work is  going splendidly and my personal  life is ...
Lila picks up a fork from the inside of her setting, not outside. Nathan blinks. Lila tastes the salad.
Um-mmm. Oh Nathan, this salad is  delish...
(clenched teeth) My God! The fork! The fork!
I'm sorry?
(strangely) Tell her, Harold... (stops himself) It's just that... It's nothing. It's  just that the outside fork is the  salad fork. One goes from the outside  in as the dinner progresses.
Oh, I'm sorry. (picks up correct  fork) I'm sorry, Nathan. I never really  learned those things.
(forced casual) No biggie.
There is a long silence as they both eat the salad.
Boy, this is good!
I'm sorry that I became so upset.
No, I'm sorry. I'm really backward  in certain areas.
(beat, blurting) It's only that I really enjoy your  company and...
You do?
Yes, and...
You really enjoy my company?
Yes. (beat, blurting) Please don't talk with food in your  mouth, Lila. Please. You're so pretty  and it only mars your... I'm sorry.  I'm being critical.
Nathan pounds his forehead with his fist. Lila waves her  hand to indicate that it's fine. She doesn't say anything because she's chewing.
It's just that I have some  peculiarities, and...
I like you, too, Nathan.
You do?
Yeah (beat) But I have some peculiarities also.
(happily) I don't care. I don't care! (then, concerned) Like what, for example?
Lila takes a deep breath, about to go into it, thinks bet of it.
Like nothing.

Nathan smiles, relieved. Lila smiles back. Nathan recoils slightly, skittishly half-points to his bared teeth. Apparently there's a piece of food stuck in Lila's teeth. She closes her mouth, runs her tongue over her teeth, smi again, mouth closed.
Rose is doing Lila's feet.
My brother says things are going  really well between you and Nathan.
I cannot believe how in love I am  with this man.
Yeah?
He's so cute. I even like his cute  little penis. It's like a little  pig's penis or something. (beat) Rose, we connect on every level.  I've finally found someone I can  feel completely safe with.
Don't throw that away. I had that  once with a guy. But I threw it away  for a cheap thrill.
One night stand?
No. I married a midget.
Marrying a midget was a cheap thrill?
Well he wasn't really a midget. He  was on the cusp of midgethood. That's  what made it cheap. Had he been an  actual midget, there would've been  nothing cheap about it, my dear.
I didn't know you were into that  sort of thing.

Let me tell you, honey, midgets are  the best kept secret in male  companionship. They're portable.  They're controllable. They're eager.  And they're exactly the right height  for a little covert oral fun on the  dance floor.
(screams with delight,  then:) I have a friend you might like to  meet.
Oh?
Three foot one.
Be still my crotch.
Rose, Nathan's no midget, but he's  asked me to move in with him.
Yeah. My brother told me.
And I think I'm going to.
(mulling it over) Stand on a stepladder sometimes.
Nathan talks.

Lila moved in with me. Did I love  her? I thought so. But from my new  vantage point I realize that love is  nothing more than a messy  conglomeration of need, desperation,  fear of death, insecurity about penis  size, and the self-involved, ego  driven need to collect other people's  hearts. Not that I judge it. (puts head in hands.  beat. looks up) Listen, I don't want to be dead yet.  Is there any way to...
Nathan looks around for some sign of another person. Ther is nobody.
No I suppose not. (beat) No biggie. Anyway, Lila moved in. We  had our problems, but we both wanted  love so badly, we turned a blind  eye.

Shut up, you.
Lila laughs and hugs her.
I like you so much, with or without  hair. (confidentially) But don't spread that around. Bad  for business.
I'm really glad you two found each  other.
Frank and Rose put their arms around each other. Frank is exactly crotch-high to Rose.

(choked) Gotta go.

Lila's car drives along. Puff looks nervously out the win

Stay.

Out.

Bad.

Get up.

Puff does. So does Lila. She is covered with hair, except for her face. But whereas Puff is now white and soft-look Lila is tan and taut and muscular. This is a reversal of way both of them were when they first met. Puff seems taken with her body.

Talking is to be kept to a minimum.  Eventually, when we are ready, there  will be none. Language was invented  so that people could lie to each  other and to themselves. There is no  other reason.
Puff begins to disagree. Lila's hand hovers over the butt He stops himself.
(confused) I agree?
Lila shocks Puff.
You lose. Any answer is the wrong  answer.

(whisper) You'll thank me eventually, Puff.  Well, you won't thank me, because we  won't be speaking, but you'll sort  of thank me with a special look, the  look a dog gives you to let you know  he loves you.
What an enchanting picture you paint  of our future together.
Lila shocks Puff once again. As he spasms, we:
Puff testifies.

And so commenced my reeducation,  gentlemen. Lila taught me so much.  She was a stern but fair teacher.  And over time, I began to remember  the carefree joy of living in a pure  state of being. But something else  happened as well, something perhaps  distinctly human... I began to fall  in love with Lila.

(despondent) I'm glad.

Yes, please, somebody ask him what  is wrong.

Nathan and Gabrielle are in bed. Nathan stares up at the  ceiling. Finally:
I want our boy back.
(sadly) Oui.
That bitch. I worked so hard. We  worked so hard, you and I. He would've  made us famous.
We still have you and I.
I know. And that's great. But it  would be great in a better way, not  a better way but a different way, if  I could find him and bring him back.
Where do we look for little lost  Puff?
I have some thoughts. I think that  hairy bitch is somewhere trying to  turn him back into an ape.
That is horrible. Apes are dirty.  No?
You better believe they're dirty!  And smelly! And messy! And they don't  know their forks from their assholes!

Nathan, seemingly in the grips of a sudden horrific migra scrunches his face and holds his ears. He relaxes a bit, gets out of bed. He walks across the room, pulls on some  pants, and picks up a container called "Stop Buggin' Me,  Sunny."
I'm going alone. This could be  dangerous.
(pulling covers up  and turning away  from him onto her  side) Okay, my sweet. Good night.
A little resistance would be nice,  damn it.
(without opening her  eyes) Please let me go with you.
No.
Okay.
Nathan is driving along a wooded dirt road. He's in his  immaculate safari suit. He looks tired. He stops the car, pulls out a gun, and gets out.
Nathan gets out of the car and runs into the woods. We fo
(yelling) Aha!

Nathan is in his underwear. He is ironing his safari suit he talks on the phone.
No luck yet, my sweet.
We see an unfolded map on the bed. There are red X's in a all the state parks along the east coast.

Lila and puff are having sex again next to a campfire. No Lila is wearing the collar, and Puff is giving her well t shocks. They giggle and kiss after they finish. Puff sits up. He holds his stomach and grunts hungrily. Lila grunts back. She stands and retrieves a sack of berries. Puff and Lila greedily, gluttonously stuff their faces. Lila takes some berries and smashes them against Puff's f She laughs heartily. He looks annoyed for a second, but t grabs a handful and squishes them against Lila's face. Pr soon they are having a berry war and are covered in purpl stains. They hug each other, out of breath and laughing.
Lila smiles.
It was paradise. (beat, sadly) At least for a tiny little while.

Lila and Puff lie naked in a tree, lazily soaking up the  midday sun. There is a rustling in the bushes. They both  look up, alert but calm. Nathan, immaculate in his safari suit, appears in the clearing. He holds a gun.
Aha! Finally. I've covered almost  the entire seaboard and parts of  eastern Ohio.
Ugnh.
Ugnh.

Oh please, is that as articulate as  you can be after all the time I spent  teaching you? We've discussed  Wittgenstein, for Christ's sake. Not  that you ever had anything very  original or challenging to say on  the subject.
Unn.
Down from the tree. Both of you.  Keep your hands where I can see them.  Don't want you pulling any weapons  out of your fur.
Nathan laughs heartily, haughtily, at his joke as Lila an Puff climb down from the tree.
Look at you two. You both disgust  me.
Oook. Oook.

Shut up! (to Puff) I gave you... life. I created you in  my image, Puff. I took you from this  primordial ooze and brought you into  the world of culture and art and  manners. And this is how you repay  me? By heading back to the ooze first  chance you get? I should leave you  here with Lila the ape woman. It  would serve you right, you ungrateful  piece of crap. But I'm not going to.  You're too valuable to me. Totally  selfish of me. You serve my purpose.  But if you had any smarts you would  realize that I serve your purpose as  well. Life is so much more delightful  when lived in a silk suit.
Ooka.
Don't worry, Lila. You can stay. I  don't have any interest in you  anymore. (to Puff) C'mon, monkey boy.
Puff looks at Lila. Lila shrugs helplessly. Puff reaches to touch her hand.
Now!

Puff looks at Lila again. She jerks her head in the direc of Nathan. Puff sighs and moves to Nathan. Nathan prods Puff, and they head off through the trees. Suddenly Puff elbows Nathan. Nathan grunts, doubles over. Puff turns, lunges, and the two wrestle on the ground. Puff pries the gun from Nathan's hand, and jumps up. Nath stands also, backing away. Puff has the gun trained on Na Lila runs to Puff, stands behind him.
Puff, put the gun down.
Ounpoo. Ungh.
Let's be reasonable human beings  here. We're all reasonable human  beings, aren't we?
(jumping up and down  like a chimp) Unka unka unka unka unka.
Look, why don't you and Lila stay  here and have your natural life.  I'll just go on my way. You'll never  see me again.
(to Lila, guiltily) I have to talk. Is that okay?
Lila nods.

(to Nathan) You did create me in your image,  Nathan. Before you I was a simple,  happy, complete being, in harmony  with the world around me. After you  I became duplicitous, cynical, angry,  anal, totally out of touch with my  surroundings. In a word, Nathan, I  became you. Lila has reintroduced me  to myself. And, incidentally, what  I'm about to do, kill you, is  something that would never have  occurred to me to do as a creature  of the Earth. Before when I killed,  it was for food or in self-defense.  Now I will kill for revenge. Revenge  is an abstract concept, Nathan. And  I learned abstract thinking from  you.
No.
Puff, don't.
Puff shoots. A crow screams. The fluttering of wings. The bullet hits Nathan in the head. He falls.
Lila sobs.
Then I shot Nathan.
Puff dabs his eye.
Then Lila shot Nathan.
Nathan talks.

Then Puff shot me. Then I died. That's  all I know. That's the end of my  story. Do I get to go to heaven now? (beat) Or is it... hell? (beat) Or... what? (beat) I just stay here, is it? I just stay  here and tell it again? And after  that? Again? And after... (sighs) Yes. Yes, of course. (sighs, clears his  throat)
We move into an extreme close-up.
(beginning again) I don't even know what sorry means  anymore. It's odd. When I was alive  I knew -- maybe it was all I knew...
Lila runs to Nathan. She kneels beside him.
He's dead.
(calmly) We bury the body. We disappear into  the woods. Nobody knows.
(beat, then quietly) No. This is the end of the road.  There's a dead human being here. For  all of his faults, he was a human  being, and certainly a victim of his  culture as much as anybody.
Forget him, Lila. We'll disappear.  We'll never talk about it again.  We'll never talk again period. I  love you.

Puff, what happened to you is as  much my fault as Nathan's. Maybe  more so, because I knew it was wrong  and I went along with it anyway. I'm  taking responsibility for the murder.  I want you to go back to your old  life.
I won't let you do that. I shot the  bastard. And I'm glad.

No. Go back to the woods. This is a  sacrifice I need to make. In my world  we have something called penance.  It's another abstraction, but I had  the concept drummed into my head  during my years in the convent. It  doesn't exist for you, and it  shouldn't. See, I could never be  free again anyway, so I might as  well be in jail.
(beat) Then I'll live for both of us, Lila.  I'll be the most free, truest animal  in the whole forest. For both of us.
(tearing up) That's what I'm counting on.
(an idea) But first I'll live among them, just  long enough to testify before congress  about the waywardness of humankind.
(shrugs) Okay. If you think it will help.
Lila, now in prison coveralls, sits in a dayroom with oth women convicts. She is watching a TV mounted on the wall. Puff is testifying.

And so, gentlemen, that is my story.  I agreed to testify before this  committee because I hoped to convey  to the American public that there is  indeed a paradise lost. Human beings  have become so enamored of their  technologies and their intellectual  prowess and their fancy gourmet foods,  that they've forgotten to look to  the Earth as a teacher. This is  hubris, my friends. And my story of  destruction and betrayal is proof of  that. I will keep my promise to Lila.  I will shed this suit and go back  into the wilderness. I will live out  my days naked and free.
Thank you, sir. Your story has touched  us all deeply. We will pass some  legislation addressing this problem.
Thank you. That is all I ask. (to camera) Good-bye, Lila. I take you with me  in my untamed heart.

Puff stands and exits the auditorium. Flashbulbs flash. In the prison common room, Lila wipes a tear from her eye She seems genuinely happy. She looks out a small barred w and sees a bluebird light there, then fly away.
Puff walks along, a man on a mission. As he walks he shed articles of clothing. He is followed by reporters and  cameramen and celebrity hounds. Soon he is naked.
Puff walks along, naked. People cheer from porches.
Puff walks along. He is still followed by reporters. Cows watch the parade.
Puff walks along a dirt road. He is about to disappear in the forest. An older woman rushes out from the crowd.
Wait!
(turning) Yes?
I saw you on C-Span. I've been looking  for you for thirty years. Then there  you were, such a beautiful, beautiful  grown man.
The older woman starts to cry.
Mother?
Yes... Derek.
Puff holds out his hand for her to shake. Flashbulbs flas
(formally) It's a pleasure to meet you, mother.  But I'm an ape like dad was... (checks watch) And I have to go back into the woods  now... forever.
(resigned) Yes, I suppose so. I suppose I knew  that was going to be what you would  say. It's good to see you again  though.
Yes.
I'm in the book, if you ever want to  drop me a line or something.
I'm an ape, mom. I'm an ape. And  apes don't drop lines.

His mother weeps. Puff gently rests his hand on her shoul for a moment, then he turns and waves to the reporters. T crowd bursts into applause. Flashbulbs flash. Puff jogs i the woods. There is a collective sigh, and then everyone  turns and heads back in the direction from which they cam We hold on the woods for a moment. A car pulls up. Puff  hurries out of the woods and jumps in the passenger side the car.
Puff leans over and kisses Gabrielle, who is driving the  car.
Hello, my little boy.
Hey, ma. Did you bring any clothes?  I'm freezing my ass off.
Oui. Nathan's silk suit, just like  you asked.
Great. (putting on suit) God, I've wanted you forever.
Gabrielle giggles. Puff kisses her.
Say my name.
Gabrielle.
(eyes glistening) You remind me so much of Nathan.
Like father, like son.
(stroking his face) You remind me so much of Nathan plus  so much of my little mongrel doggie.
Woof.
This turns Gabrielle on. She kisses him passionately. Whe the kiss runs its course, Puff speaks.
Arf.
Gabrielle kisses him again, even more passionately this t
As much as I loved Nathan, I'm not  sorry she killed him, if it means I  can have you. Is that a terrible  thing to say, my sweet?

(putting her finger  to his lips) Hush. No, it is never terrible to be  in love. Nathan's memory lives on in  our sacred union. (beat) I'm not sorry she killed him either.  Nathan was wonderful. He was erudite  and sophisticated and charming. You  are all that, too. But you have  something more. You have a bit of  the animal in you.
They smile flirtatiously at each other. Puff leans over a kisses Gabrielle's neck.
Let's go eat, I'm starved.
French?
Oui.

The car makes a screeching u-turn. It disappears in the  direction of the city. When the dust clears, we see the t white mice standing there on the side of the road, shiver and emaciated. The male holds out his the thumb and the f holds a tiny little sign which reads: New York. There is a look of hopelessness in their beady black eyes FADE OUT.
